comments.commentBody: Double the recipe and stack 4 layers.
What if you are baking a cake for 40 people? All adults
Coriander and cilantro are NOT the same thing.

You can always make this kind of dish vegetarian. If it doesn't have enough flavor for you, experiment with spices (cumin and smoked paprika for example) and fresh herbs (even just parsley and cilantro).

Used actual langostini from Costco (pre-cooked.) Drained them in a colander over a bowl, collected the juice and used it along with wine in the sauce. Also thickened it in the end with extra butter. Forgot to get parsley but used cilantro. Saute'd the langoustines sparingly - about a minute and a half while fresh capellini were boiled. Drained the pasta and put it in the scampi pan, mixing well with sauce and seafood. Sprinkled parmesan on final pasta dish. Result got raves.
What's wrong with fresh pasta?

Followed the suggestion to use a stick mixer rather than a blender. Liked that it left the sauce with still more texture than that provided by adding the 1/4 c corn near the end. Served it mixed with tortellini filled with prosciutto rather than adding a meat/fat to the sauce. Wish I'd tried the mint for some variety rather than basil :)
Does anyone else blanch their basil first? That's how I was taught to make pesto-- in order to preserve the bright green color.  And, note: walnuts are not a bad substitution for pignolinas--
I do the curry thing, too, but only for me and my husband. The rest of America wants theirs plain, no dill or olives, and certainly NO curry, please. Phillistines!
My trouble spot as well.
had some trouble in the SW which was the last to fall. Did not know martial arts or temple of Artemis location. finally got enough crossings to finish.
I just remembered that ANI used to be overused crosswordese for "Blackbird." I wonder whether BEQ realized that he had created a new clue for an old set of letters?

and Elke
Thought I was on EASY street because EXURBIA led to EXPORT TAX which brought me to XANADU. Quickly got the NE corner, after all the TED LECTURE annual convention is now a local event.
But then used up at least 18 minutes trying to come up with JELLO SHOT. Never heard of it, along with FLAGRANT FOUL which I first read as Fragrant (thinking it reflected a HOT smelly game ). LOL.
Had Sammy KAHN ; had to google for NUNCHAKUS and EPHESUS. Did remember Eric HEIDEN and the shouts of USA USA accompanying his feats .
Liked the clue for NEST ; and nose/noise diff. -AN I.
Bottom line- puzzle seemed more like a Saturday than Friday. But am not saying NO FAIR . Just GAH...
Maybe I need to do more BEQ puzzles . How about it ?

Competing for the title of "first" is the American Thompson sub-machine gun - of Prohibition fame that was also used by US Marines. My vote for "first" goes to the German MP-18 - a WWI rifle that could fire at a rate of 500 round per minute - astounding for the time and deadly in the trenches.

I have been unable to find statistics of mass murders prior to 1940.
The only one that come to mind is the St Valentine's Day massacre. Assault rifles were easily had prior to 1940. What is different about today that we have so many? Is it mental illness?

The Sturmgewehr was the world's first assault rifle. It literally means Storm Rifle as in Assault Rifle. M-16's, M-4's and AK-47 are true weapons of war and used by terrorists worldwide.

Please note virtually no mass killings in the US use these weapons which have automatic fire capabilities. They are illegal to own or possess in the US. Most crimes committed with "assault rifles" use run of the mill semi-automatic rifles that are designed to look like the real thing. A semi-automatic rifle can be purchased at most Walmart's or sporting good stores. Most hunting rifles are semi-automatic weapons.

The result of this change would make the candidates who cannot be everywhere spend more time, attention, and ad money in the largest states. I do not think it would give greater clarity, but raise the cost of running. For certain. And electors not being divisable, while 40% or 60% will not come out a whole number thereof will show further inequity.
More complexity to no end.
That's not how the electoral college works, Nick. It's designed to perpetuate the two-party system. And there is no way Johnson could take a single state. Not going to happen.

Yes
Libertarians are for small government; which results in many liberal social policies. People that are against Libertarians often pigeon hole their entire platform as crazy. This year the other options are crazy.
Sorry I didn't expand on this, but that wasn't my point.
I do appreciate your comments, as it is a valid opinion
Thanks

It's not the students.

It's the common cause the administrators make with the students against their common enemy: faculty who regard intellectual life as the heart and soul of education.

Everything is easier for the administration when faculty are docile and discouraged from promoting genuine thinking. Student satisfaction -- which comes from getting what they think they want rather than what they don't know they need -- and the institutional status that comes with it, increase, at least short term, when faculty are cowed out of challenging students, and the best way of cowing faculty is for the administration to encourage students to make demands from the left, since we liberal faculty rarely feel comfortable sounding more conservative than our students.

If schools returned to their mission of teaching rather than catering, things would be better all around.

It is astonishing that young college students enrolled full-time at elite colleges (a luxury that was unimaginable to previous generations) are convinced they are the most oppressed and victimized people in the country, even though the 35% of Americans who don't get to go to college are clearly the disadvantaged ones. You would never know it from the endless grievances, the victim Olympics, demands to be excused from class to attend protests, demands for trigger warnings, for grading leniency because world news is upsetting, the mandatory sorting and categorizing of everyone based on skin color, sexual orientation, religion, or ethnicity, as if their character and abilities and talent are meaningless unless we know their exact placement on the Pyramid of Oppression... all of this reflects poorly on college students of today.
I respect for college activists who devote their efforts to improving the world, but that's not what this is. Do you think these students care at all about their peers who weren't fortunate enough to go to college, who are working low-wage jobs to support themselves and their families? Of course not! This is all about them and how cushy they can make their four years at college, how well they can train the cowering administrators to cave to their every whim.
Colleges are allowing themselves to be governed by the demands of teenagers, and it’s alarming. Providing an education in the classical liberal tradition is apparently not even an afterthought.

I think there is something new here. While I agree that movements on campuses have always been "wide-spread" and "confined to a minority of students", the issues these students are passionate about extend beyond the campus. The resulting intense media coverage, including social medias, has caused administrators to make make changes in response to pressure more easily than in previous generations. Alumni are reacting to this by closing their wallets in some cases, and money talks. I'm assuming those mentioned in the article are white. Perhaps they feel that in trying to appease cultural demands, some of their culture, good or bad, is disappearing as a result. Ask any Trump supporter.

Each generation needs a critique of society and its problems to use as a launching pad for their own take over of power and influence. First, gather in groups and come up with ideas. Spread those ideas and use them as a springboard. In this case, everyone who came before them is wrong and a society organized in any way against their interests, their comfort and their glorious future is not just wrong, but seen as evil. This is an obsessive, destructive and self defeating way of looking at the world. It reminds me nothing so much as the Red Brigades in China and the kind of ideas that led to Pol Pot's genocide in Cambodia. I don't mean it would necessarily lead to such drastic results, but it is dangerous nonetheless. Ideas bent in the wrong direction and pursued to conclusion can be enormously destructive. It is too bad that the people on the scene, professors and administrators, aren't pushing back hard.

I am a Vassar alum who has contributed regularly for decades.  2016 will be my last year of donations and I'm happy to see the president of the college move on.  Vassar and its president have received a lot of good publicity for reaching out to more students from middle class and poor backgrounds.  In terms of admissions and financial aid, it's the upper middle class that doesn't find the welcome mat.  The sons and daughters of rich alums still get the royal treatment when it comes to admissions.  So do the kids who are first generation college students.  No wonder Vassar is in turmoil because of BDS. The campus is missing the kids that are the bridge between the rich, middle class and lower middle class. Quite frankly, it is the upper middle class that is squeezed out because the $70,000 price tag for tuition, room and board.

So Indian food is not American food, but pizza, soup dumplings and Frankfurters are? Sehr interessant, but I would think some Indian-Americans might be a bit disappointed at this news. Bindi masala is about the only way you can get me to eat my okra. Oh, well, maybe it's a good thing. We can't risk terrorizing our students with hummus, and I've heard burritos are intoxicating.

You really can't make this stuff up, can you? Enjoyed your comment.

I never had the opportunity or means to go to a private liberal university, but I think I can relate to the dismay of some of the alumni mentioned in this article. I am not white or male but I am fed up with this touchy-feely sense of outrage at totally superficial issues or events. I read with laughter and incredulity,  recent opposition to serving Indian food at a campus cafeteria on grounds of 'cultural appropriation'. Give me a break. Who has time to sit in for this? We have reached heights of intolerance on both ends and are veering towards reverse racism. I can not stand obliterating older books buildings or art because times have changed. They all are testament to our history, our successes, failures and how far we have come. Build new things, create new art and bring forth new heroes for our time. Don't wrongly judge well meaning stalwart citizens who were products of their times (especially those who are no longer alive to clarify their true intentions or have a choice to act differently knowing what we know now).
Something in the histoplasmosis family? Some travel to the southwest was noted.

ESR, CRP elevated, non FE anemia, left shift CBC and CT of dangerously swollen cervical lymphs suggests a potentially serious Castlemans Disease;  yet I'm thrown off by the note about the anal rash early on in this little boy's course of symptoms.   Says he and his family live among a Noah's Ark of family pets despite his near 7 year history of allergy(s)-  he could be infested with a vector.  Don't see any fecal ova/parasite results in the notes presented here.  Poor little guy.

I read the article on Harvard's attack on the private clubs and was wondering if alumnae might stop giving. Ironically this would hurt many of the students who are protesting for greater sensitivity, since many of these universities give full scholarships to those in need, which includes larger numbers of minority. That would be  a tragedy. I would hate to see free speech impeded ever. University is a great opportunity to experiment, to push the boundaries, to say whatever you think and deal with and learn from the response. I guess this is something for the kids to think about, but I also think the culture is changing and yes, some of the old white men might feel alienated. I guess then the universities need to hope their younger, hipper, more diverse graduates will earn enough to make up the difference.

"... by educating themselves on ever-present topics such as racism and sexism."

OK, what do you know about Woodrow Wilson, and how do you feel the mural depicting him that was in a dining hall at Princeton University?

At Princeton, Woodrow Wilson, a Heralded Alum, Is Recast as an Intolerant One
By ANDY NEWMAN
NOV. 22, 2015
http://www.nytimes.com/2015/11/23/nyregion/at-princeton-addressing-a-rac...

Ashley, I want to congratulate your generation on the Bill of Rights, the Emancipation Proclamation, the national parks, Women's suffrage, the New Deal, the Civil Rights Act, Earth Day and a host of other advances that the alumni's generations never contemplated.  Woodstock really rocked, but what impresses me most of all is the work Gen Why has done on fire and the wheel.  Hope the speech and writing project works out.

This article has aspects of economic as well as social issues. We live in the 21st century now-- a world "plagued" with socially-aware youth who have formed opinions different than those of their parents and grandparents by educating themselves on ever-present topics such as racism and sexism. While I personally disagree with some of the forms of protests from the current students and the reasons behind them, I also feel that generation gap between them and the alumni is the major source of misunderstanding. The youth now are trying to deal with issues the alumni's generations never solved, and thus the alumni will fire back in the best way they know how-- cut the funding. Unfortunately, the younger generation has the underhand when it comes to money, portraying us as reliant and needy when that is not at all what we want. We want to be independent and make our own way, solve our own problems and fix our parents mistakes. Economically and socially, Generation Y is about to take over the world. The Silent Generation got it's name for a reason, and Generations Y and Z will not be silent.
Well said!

Having retired 5 years ago after 48 years of university teaching, I may have lost touch with current trends.   But there appears to be an intolerance genuine discussion and differences of opinion.  During the Vietnam War era students protested against genuine injustices and moral outrages; today they seem mostly offended that their limited view of history and the world is not exclusively dominant.    This is scary for free speech and our political system, which is already facing epoch challenge from Donald Trump.    What happens when the intolerance of the Trumpsters meets the intolerant student "left"?   Or will it just blend into the intolerance of the next generation of Trump supporters.

Balance, and a larger perspective, please!
It is fine for students to look at the perceived failings of men and women of the past, including those of the individuals who founded their institutions. It is also instructive to look at the good they may have done as well, and to consider them in the context of the era in which they lived. In addition, it would also be instructive to look at them from the standpoint of what was happening in other parts of the world in the same era.
